review_detailed_main: I went in having no idea what it was about and was compelled to watch by Nathalie Emmanuel, even though the beginning was average (but necessary). The Invitation is a gothic horror film that involves an American young woman in New York who, through a free DNA testing kit, finds out that she has relatives in UK. The relatives then invite her to a lavish wedding on an old manor in England.

The two main leads, Nathalie Emmanuel and Thomas Doherty, are both amazing. They're both captivating and they have chemistry. But that's pretty much it, to be honest. review_title: Absolutely loved it, until the last 30 mins.
The Light of The Moon was better because at least it knew what it was.
review_detailed_main:
This film can't decide what kind of movie it was to be or what kind of tone it was to have.

Jessica M. Thompson continues to improve, giving us a more tense and spooky experience than The Light of the Moon. I wish it had a similar tonal shift like that film had though. I didn't like the splashes of the supernatural we got throughout the film, and I would have much rather preferred it he ambiguous whether or not they're vampires (or even just really eccentric) sort of like George A. Romero's Martin.

The first thirty minutes or so have a lot of Get Out parallels, just in the way the story is set up. At one point, she goes for a run at night for no reason, just like in Get Out, but then the movie veers into a totally different direction and doesn't feel like such a blatant copy. I'm glad her best friend wasn't in it too much because I think it would have distracted me from the drama/mystery of the story.

The scene from the trailer where they're like having dinner really got me hooked, and it really helped get me invested for the last thirty minutes of the film, but it felt too little too late after already teasing us so much. I think this film should have saved its supernatural aspects for those final minutes rather than sprinkling them throughout, it would have made the reveal so much more impactful. I basically wish the film tricked you into thinking it's a drama/thriller, but I am not at all discrediting the movie for what I wanted it to be.

I really don't think this was a great movie, but it was decently-shot. I liked a lot of the performances and I felt like I could always tell what was happening (like in the dark) which is important to me in a horror movie. Not that everything needs to be shown, I just don't think dark = scary. I also really liked the long black nails the vampires had and I thought their teeth didn't look too fake or cheesy.

Nathalie Emmanuel did a great job as the lead in this film, but Thomas Doherty really stole the show for me here. He was so hot in this movie (I would let him bite me lol).

It's worth a watch if you really like vampires or are bored. I did have some fun though, but I don't think you need to rush out to theatres for this one. It would be just as good at home on your television.

review_detailed_main:

A few moments in the film, and towards the end, racially fixated comments are made about "white men" "whitest man ever" which I found was inappropriate and racist.

Good character development is seen throughout with memorable scenes, occasional jumps, nervous laughs.

The film fits the categories well, thriller, mystery, drama are all present. The design of set, dialogue, and general appearance of the film is well done.

If you want an interesting film that will keep you engaged until the end (skip the last 2 minutes or so of social engineering) then I recommend this film.

review_title: Now we have Racist vampires and not in an ironic way!!
review_detailed_main:
So we have a movie about a vampire family in """England""" who so very very easily persuade a multi racial American lady to join them. Its a pretty basic ride from beginning to end. But considering the people involved I am kinda surprised how basic it really was.... Felt like one of those movies with too many producers involved, You know the ones.

No spoilers there.

The movie is ok for people who maybe have never seen a movie before. As others have stated, its an obvious copy of many other movies which isnt necessarily a bad thing. No idea is original. But at least make an effort to put some original content in there.

Remember all those old black and white British Dracula, Vampire and Mummy movies? I really loved the camp almost childlike scaryness of them, I still do. Well this movie really reminded me of them...except those movies were made about 60yrs ago, so thats not really a good thing.

But of my pet hates in modern movie making, the ones used in this movie are surely the worst.....Like the idea of taking a very basic premise for a story and needlessly socialising it just to please the execs. I mean--- racist Vampires???? Who would have thought it? Do vampires have any dog in that race?, excuse the pun. If its to do with pure bloodlines then why invite her at all??? Adds less than nothing to the story.

More pet hates??? How about a snivelling weak baby suddenly becoming a supreme badass out of no where..No training, No previous skills..just boom, badass!! YAWN!!.

How about making set pieces so ridiculous that even a drunk child would question the writing.... I mean the ending made my nose bleed.lol.

But genuinely it wouldn't have taken much to actually make a decent little B movie. And I honestly mean that.

Leave the social commentary to movies where it may make sense or Give her some help along the way, I know why they didnt but it would make more sense. Maybe get her to ask the obvious questions. Remember the fantastic 5 or whatever they were called? How they tried to solve stuff they had questions to? They were kids for kids..she is a full grown adult lady who has no questions at all????

Well you get the point . A movie made because they got money from a studio. That is really all i can believe.

Watch it, dont watch it....your life wont change either way.

review_title: The Invitation - Another Dreary Horror Failure

I don't know if it's the pandemic, the paucity of new pitches, or just a temporary downturn, but the same crappy plots keep popping up every month or so. The cliche-ridden horror movies are among them. The Invitation is the latest of the mind-numbing turkeys that have come out this year. Is it the film schools that are failing, or is Hollywood just out of new ideas for horror films? Watching these films is like watching paint dry. If I didn't have a free pass to all film from my brother-in-law who is a theater manager, I would never go see half of these films that are out in 2022.

It's too rushed, too absurdly contrived, to overloaded with attempted lore. It needed to be longer and it needed to be R. It needed to lean in and own it's premise instead of pulling punches.

And it needed much much better actors.

review_title: 10 mins in and I'm just angry.
review_detailed_main:
I didn't only watch 10mins, that was just when I started wanting to punch the writer and director in their stupid, racist, ignorant faces.

There was no need for the whole "who dated white guys?" conversation, certainly not with the comment about therapy. Dating outside your race is not a mental illness.

England has no colonial guilt, colonisation is how most countries were settled. It certainly has no guilt over the actions of a group of religious fanatics who decided to steal someone else's country.

Sleeping with a black man was in no way scandalous in the 20's, unlike America, England disnt feel the need to keep the races pure. (Seriously, England's black queen is a main character in a popular series, that started 2 years before this rubbish was made.)

Vans full of virtual slaves and catering supplies aren't brought in for parties. The staff (maids, butlers etc) who don't live on the grounds are just like everyone else, they drive to work, do their jobs and go home.

And if a white person described a black family as "extremely black" they'd be lynched. It isn't any less repulsively racist for a black woman to say it.

Apart from all that, the film was just a crap amalgamation of a handful of gothic horrors and Ready or Not, with little attempt to hide the lack of a single original thought, or a total lack of understanding of the films. Even if the trailer hadn't made it obvious what the family's dark secret was, it was pretty clear long before the big reveal; by which point I was already bored, and kinda hoping someone would throw Evie into a deep hole somewhere. I only finished watching this dreck out of fairness, if I'm going to trash it in the reviews, I should watch the whole thing. And I massively regret watching till the end! I'm not sure if it was the utter laziness or the pathetic cliches that I found more insulting, but I'm actually angry that someone paid for this and inflicted it on others.

review_title: Ready Or Not but with fangs

review_detailed_main:
In the intro some woman hangs herself in a mansion.

A catering girl serving arrogant rich people during some corporate event decides to send in a DNA-ancestry test from the company sponsoring the event. Now that she's in the databases she can look up her distant relatives. One of them contacts her. It's some Brit. He invites her to the wedding of some relatives there.

She reluctantly (TM) goes then to this all expenses-paid trip to a British castle. She right away has a run in with the arrogant chief butler as the abused catering girls arrive, with whom she connects immediately. Then she meets the owner of the castle who "saves her" from the butler. They are attracted to each other. Tuns out the entry hall of the mansion is the place where the woman in the intro hanged herself. There are some huge monster statues all over the place. She is told she can't go into the library. At night she discovers the location of the hidden library key. Later we see how the butler sends one of the catering girls in there. Let's just say she doesn't fare well. Our girl is introduced to the whole family, which is almost entirely made up of guys.

Next day she meets 2 bridesmaids. A sweet and friendly one, and a creepy arrogant one who keeps pushing our girl's buttons, which is easy to do since she has a huge chip on her shoulder. Our girl gets closer and closer to the mansion owner who suggests they should marry and she sort of agrees. Later that day there's a family dinner where guy announces, much to girl's shock, the wedding of the two. So this meeting is of three families that have been connected for centuries. The fourth missing family member is finally present--the girl. And in marriage then all of them will prosper. Then butler brings in a catering girl, slashes her throat and passes on glasses of blood for folks to drink.

Turns out mansion owner is a big time vampire who needs the girl to keep the line going. During the wedding they will exchange blood which will turn her into a vampire and give him strength. Of course she's not interested in massive wealth and eternal life, what American would be... So she has other plans for the wedding.

The Invitation then comes across as a vampire-themed version of Get Out with an unappealing cinematography reminiscent of Euphoria. I'm glad someone finally made a vampire movie with a budget. Unfortunately the politics, casting, and poor cinematography don't help the story much. Missing is also more violence, gore, sensuality--in other words everything a vampire horror flick should have.

Its just so simple, the story, the acting, the production, the effects,, just simple - this is a typical 3-6 rated movie - you can slow watch it in the background while you play with your mobile or watch it the day after when you halfsleep, but dont look on it in a cozy moment like Friday evning or something like that, its not that good , its mostly boring, the horror is only things you have seen before, stolen from other movies and not good movies either

I saw the trailer, and couldn't wait to see the actual movie, but unfortunately that turned out as a major disappointment. It was all way too much and over the top. I guess you maybe could label it as some sort of grand guignol, but even so it really lacked even the slightest credibility: the settings, the costumes, the dialogues, everything was overblown for the supposed effect, and practically all characters were over-acted. Apart from a few jump-scares with according crashing sound-blows, there wasn't so much scary stuff going on, while the gore-rate was equally moderate. Nathalie Emmanuel is lovely to look at (although I kept being annoyed by her unbecoming nose-piercing), and Thomas Doherty is as handsome as a walking Leyendecker advertisement (which of course suited his true nature fine), but these two couldn't save this project on their own. Sean Pertwee making a silly caricature of his Alfred-character in Gotham didn't help either. Maybe a touch of humor would have, but alas, no laughs here. Just a deep sigh.

review_title: like a number of these sorts of movies, it's OK not great

review_detailed_main:
The Invitation is a Gothic Romance Horror. If you don't like romance in your horror movies and thought Crimson Peak was boring, this movie is not for you. But those of us who do enjoy this kind of movie are treated to a great experience, complete with ancient mansions, ghostly figures roaming dark hallways, preternatural love, cold-blooded murder, and dramatic Baroque statues.

Director Jessica M Thompson clearly understands the genre, its conventions and tropes, Nathalie Emmanuel is fantastic as the fish-out-of-water Evie, and Thomas Doherty does a fine job as Count De Ville.

There are definitely a few scares sprinkled throughout, but this is not a jump scare-a-minute kind of movie.

5.7/10

This film definitely had me going in the first half, as it's been awhile since I've seen a horror, so I was genuinely spooked for the first bit. However, once I settled into the movie and got a grasp on who and what I was watching, boredom kind of settled in.

The story feels very similar to "Ready or Not" (2019) with one glaring difference being vampires are in one and not the other. The story here had me intrigued me throughout, but it didn't sit right with its execution, and the finale feels rushed with no care for the build-up of characters and story.

The acting won't be receiving any awards, but it wasn't terrible. Each actor was suited for the role they were cast for, and because there seemed to be commitment, it made the story more enjoyable and worth giving the chance.

Shadows were essential to building the tension, and worked very well with the cinematography, as nothing was revealed sooner than it should've been. However, action sequences lacked. To give the look of something crazy and exciting happening, a lot of unnecessary cuts were used, and therefore made the visuals seem a bit much near the end.

Overall, for the style of movie that was presented. I personally would A) recommend waiting to see this movie on a streaming service; and B) recommend watching "Ready or Not" (2019) (6/10), as it's pretty well the same movie, but without vampires.

review_title: Bit of a snooze fest for the first 70 mins
review_detailed_main:
The Invitation is a case of don't trust strangers (even if they say they're family), and sometimes things are too good to be true.

This film starts off intriguing but is more mysterious than scary. I found myself waiting for the action to kick off, even after an hour in to it. When it finally does, there's less than half an hour left, and the final scene is extremely cringeworthy.

I was hoping this film would be similar to Ready or Not (2019) and while it has glimpses of it, it fails to give the lead the same badass heroine character as Samara Weaving's in Ready or Not.

Nathalie Emmanuel (most known for Game of Thrones) is a good actress, just waiting for her Hollywood breakthrough role. This film sadly isn't that.

On a positive note, The Invitation has a great set design, and for a mostly dark lit film, it has great cinematography.

And you know what movie you're in for.

When she arrived at the "English" manor, in the United Kingdom, the Rolls Royce is left hand drive. That told me all I needed to know.

Why are these movies so dreadfully poorly executed beyond "hot girl/hot guy/creepy mansion/evil lurking"? Not a step was missed to plonk in every tired "horror" trope and schtick. What noob goes wondering about at night for a glass of water? And in a mansion like that the room would have bottled water. Gimme a break! I'm sure the target audience of 15 year olds "appreciate" this movie but I find it hard to believe movie studios actually expect to make a profit in this dreck.

Trailers didn't give everything away, plot was good, acting was good. Nothing super special but certainly an entertaining movie and that's what matters. This was a real slowburner with a relatively unsatisfying ending. It's just... meh. Not great, but not terrible. A lot of horror movies are that way; writing horror is HARD. Imo, it's one of the hardest movie genres to do right, which leads us to a movie like this.

It had a really great buildup if you're willing to be patient. I definitely recommend doing something else (have dinner, do some crafts, doodle, etc) while watching it, since it's not the most stimulating buildup on account of how slow it was. I think the actors did a fantastic job, which is something I don't feel we see enough of in horror! The cast was gorgeous, the sets were impeccable, and the cinematography was very pleasing on the eye.

I didn't see any trailers for it, but I've heard that they spoil everything for the movie, so heads up that you may not enjoy it as much if you've seen trailers. Some of the dialogue was a crime against writing, and, as always with horror, the actions of the main character didn't really make sense. Then again, the genre wouldn't exist if it didn't revolve around idiots, would it? From my perspective, a lot of the plot twists seemed completely obvious, and the suspense was kept in just not revealing it yet. Making you doubt yourself.

If it were me, I think I would have gone for a funny ending. I really believe the place where this film failed is in its ending. The biggest letdown for me was that the movie seemed to take itself too seriously, but didn't pack the same punch that an excellently done horror ending would have provided. I know many people would have been let down by a serious buildup and a funny ending, but I think it would have been easier for the writers and director to pull off than what actually happened. In the sense of the ending, it was too predictable, and I think that's what made it unpalatable.

review_title: I see too many ideas clashing with each other
review_detailed_main:
What was this film meant to be? And I am not being rhetorical; that was an actual query, for real, what was this movie trying to be? Cause, I have watched not one but numerous ideas floating around.

At one juncture it tries to show off the thrills, in the next, the priorities seem to change and it suddenly becomes so romantically involved, and then again, after a certain period of time, this deviated toward the conventional Horror route (Jumpscares, Blue color tones, Slow Pans, you know, all those usual stuff); as a result, instead of realizing its true, underneath potential, the film turns into incoherent chaos.

Look, I'm not at all criticizing them for having different sets of ideas; it's always a good thing to have versatility, especially in such a creative medium, but looking at the script and the kind of subject it wanted to deal with, I feel like the makers needed to have an unambiguous vision, for them to emphasize one particular tone not many! A combination of too many elements won't always sit well.

Vampires in movies date way back to the early days of cinema; we hate them, we love them, but there is one thing for sure they are not going anyway anytime soon and will continue to prey upon us on the big screen for years to come. Now once again, we end the summer sinking our teeth into another vampire flick. Unfortunately, this one is pretty soulless (literally.)

The film opens up with Evie (Nathalie Emmanuel), a city girl living in New York City trying to make it big in the big apple, working as a caterer and trying to make ends meet, and being a struggling artist, still grieving the death of her parents she incredibly lonely and desperate for a family. However, through a series of dumb events, not always entirely dumb, sometimes we want to know the background of our family, but she uses one of those DNA tests, and she learns that she has a second cousin, Oliver (Hugh Skinner). Even while her best friend Grace (Courtney Taylor) tells her, it's not a good idea to go meet a said cousin. He convinces her to travel to London, where she finds out she is a part of this royal family that she had no idea about, and oh, by the way, yes, Olivia is indeed a vampire. Now in London, what we essentially have come to is a sexier, hornier, vampirism-infused Downtown Abby.

Walt DeVille (Thomas Doherty), a close friend of the Alexanders, sweeps Evie off her feet in a manner consistent with the form and tone of any gothic romance story. Despite all of the warning signs, Evie is obviously star-struck by Walt, starting with their awkward first encounter when she confronts the irate and unpleasant valet, Mr. Fields (Sean Pertwee). Still, Walt comes in and, as one might anticipate, immerses Evie in her fairy tale, sending butterflies fluttering through your stomach. The romance and chemistry between Evie and Walt are dashing as one would imagine them to be. The actors put on a great performance; doing so, however, does feel like a bit of twilight chemistry, but these kinds of films are our guilty pleasure, so I roll with it here. I should also mention the set design from Felicity Abbott totally gets it right with dressing the manor, and its grounds, from the fabrics to the statues, are exquisite and absolutely stunning,

Though, there aren't any real scares. For all you horror aficionados, if you're expecting scares from this, you might think differently about what you're getting into. This film is more about the vibes and not the gory and chilling horror. I think the movie is very misleading in terms of being an outright horror film; if we just stuck with the premise of being a Gothic, sexy, romantic vampire flick, it probably would have done some good for it. However, The movie has issues about race and social class that is dangled in front of an audience but its never fully developed. Though it is nice to see another film touching these subjects other than Jordan Peele, it doesn't need to be a Get Out rip-off, but it could have been developed a little more.

All this said, The Invitation takes so long to get anywhere. By the time you reach the end, the climax is about to happen; it ends before you even realize it. The script spends so much time building up to this moment, just to have it all come to an end as fast as lightning; the credits are rolling. The Invitation is not the worst horror film (if you can call it a horror film), but it's not the greatest either. It's as soulless as a vampire.

review_title: Relies so heavily on horror clichés that even genre novices would struggle to find anything remotely scary about it
review_detailed_main:
"The Invitation" is a horror thriller film directed by Jessica M. Thompson ("The Light of the Moon"). Starring Nathalie Emmanuel in the lead role, it relies so heavily on horror clichés that even genre novices would struggle to find anything remotely scary about it.

In New York City, Evelyn "Evie" Jackson (Nathalie Emmanuel) works as a waitress for a catering company to help make a living. At the urging of a friend, Evie takes a DNA test and discovers that she has relatives in England, with a cousin named Oliver (Hugh Skinner) currently located within the City. After meeting up, Oliver invites Evie to accompany him back to England for a family wedding set to take place shortly, which she accepts after some initial hesitation. Upon arriving at the lavish estate, Evie is courted by the lord of the manor Walter De Ville (Thomas Doherty), whom she is charmed by his sophistication and wealth at his disposal. As the wedding date draws closer, Evie starts to notice strange occurrences at night, learning that her newfound family is hiding a dark, sinister secret from the world.

It seems a natural curiosity for us to want to trace our family roots, as it could help discover important things about who we are and why we're at this particular point in history. Thanks to websites like "Ancestry.com" and "23andMe", modern technology has allowed for easier, more streamlined tracking of our genealogy that can produce results in as early as a matter of days. But the reality is that in life, sometimes it's best to live in blissful ignorance since the deeper we keep digging, the more likely we'll find something that we might not like. The film "The Invitation" tries to use a concept like this to elicit fear in the viewer, but it fails in just about every way imaginable.

To the film's credit, I think the idea of somebody learning that their family history hides a monstrous secret is actually a pretty decent plotline for a horror movie. The problem here is that everything is so poorly executed that I can't imagine too many people who would find anything to be afraid of while sitting through the whole thing. For a start, the film just isn't scary at all. And since this is supposed to be a horror film, that's a huge problem. The first scene that should be considered scary, which takes place in a dark room where the candles keep blowing out, leaves so little to be desired that by the time it's over you can't even comprehend what just happened. There's no attempt to build any suspense or tension during this scene nor is there any frightening payoff once we figure out what was supposed to have made us fearful in the first place. I'm not sure whether this should be blamed on bad writing, bad direction, or both, but it certainly set the stage for everything else to come.

In addition to the lack of scares, the film is also so reliant on the overused tropes of other better horror pictures that it almost borders on comical. Everything from the large mysterious mansion with conveniently out-of-bounds rooms to the obligatory jump scares that are revealed to only be a dream are played up to ridiculous levels. I actually lost count of how many times I rolled my eyes at these moments, in hindsight I probably should have written each of them down instead. Because of this, the film is a predictable bore the entire way through. Even if you aren't a fan of horror movies, you can't help but notice how desperate this film is to entertain us with what it perceives to be clever writing, but all it does is come across as cookie-cutter modern horror flick that makes you wish you were watching something else instead.

Considering the bland material she had to work with, I suppose Nathalie Emmanuel tried her best to give as convincing a performance as possible in such an awful film like this. At the same time though, I am reluctant to call Evie the best thing about the film when her character is nothing more than a typical Mary Sue. Practically everything about Evie's character is perfect; she's beautiful, she's confident, she's a talented artist, she has no notable flaws (unless you count low finances as a flaw), and every problem she encounters she manages to overcome all by herself nearly right away. As a result of this, I didn't have any attachment to her or felt any sympathy for what she goes through because I know what's going to happen to her regardless. The only redeeming thing is that at least Emmanuel knows how to cry on cue when necessary, though even something like that is hardly worth defending.

There is little else to say about the rest of the cast, except perhaps Thomas Doherty as Walter De Ville. If there's such thing as a Mary Sue equivalent for objects of affection, then Walter fits that bill perfectly. Every one of his character traits is taken right out of the stereotype catalogue of male love interests who are irresistible to women; he has a foreign accent (a British accent would sound exotic to an American), he's sophisticated, he's well-dressed, he's handsome, he has a chiselled body, and he lives in a big mansion because he's incredibly rich for reasons unknown. Though all of this would seem too good to be true for an intelligent female protagonist, not once does Evie ever question this, even after she deduces that things seem amiss. This character is nothing more than a shameless self-inserted fantasy by the writer for lonely female viewers to ogle over. When both the film's main characters are Mary Sues, you know there's a major problem.

Whether you like horror films, thriller films, or even romance films, I can tell you now that "The Invitation" fails to appeal to fans of all of these genres. The whole thing comes across as a dull hodgepodge of horror clichés, poorly written characters, an uninteresting story, and a general lack of reason to exist. There are so many better horror films out there that I would rather have spent my time watching than something like this. My only hope is that my warning is heeded to stay away lest you desire a bad product.
